Our first screening for the semester is Battle Royale, one of Kinji Fukasaku's most well known and beloved films. Following a group of schoolchildren forced by a dystopian government to fight to the death, Battle Royale is one of Japan's most praised and influential cinematic exports.

***

Find us this Wednesday in the Old Geology Lecture Theatre. We'll have pizza from 5, with the screening starting around 5:15. We'll be heading to the Forest Lodge Hotel afterwards for post-film drinks and discussion.

This event is free for members, $5 for Access cardholders. Annual membership is $5 for Access cardholders.

event_name: Filmsoc x Dogesoc: End of Semester Mystery Movie
description:
Filmsoc and Dogesoc are teaming up to end the semester with a bang this coming Wednesday.

We'll be screening a MYSTERY dog related film, the identity of which will be revealed shortly before the screening starts. As always, plenty of FREE pizza, garlic bread, and soft drinks will be provided. Doors open at 5, and the film will start around 5:20.

Entry is free for all Filmsoc and Dogesoc members, $5 for non-members and $10 for non-access card holders.

This week, Filmsoc presents the darkly humorous, high octane British crime film "Sexy Beast". A retired ex-Con living the expat hi-life in Spain is persuaded to take up one last job, with epic consequences.
Free Pizza and Drinks provided
place: R.C. Mills Building- University Of Sydney

description:
Come see Satoshi Kon, one of anime's most celebrated auteurs, and his thought-provoking look into Japanese idol culture and the mental effects of fame. Incredibly animated and psychologically taught "Perfect Blue" is easily one of the best feature Anime films.

Free pizza & drinks provided
place: R.C. Mills Building- University Of Sydney

description:
This week, Filmsoc presents one of the masterpieces of Iranian New Wave, Mohsen Makhmalbaf's "Moment of Innocence" . An innovative docudrama, looking at an event from Makmalbaf's own past through multiple viewpoints - a must-see for fans of Kiarostami's "Close Up" or anyone with an interest in Iranian cinema in general

Free pizza and drinks provided
place: R.C. Mills Building- University Of Sydney

event_name: Filmsoc Presents: Funeral Parade of Roses
description:
This week, Filmsoc presents Toshio Matsumoto's magnum opus "Funeral Parade of Roses." A masterpiece of the Japanese underground of the 60s, this is a disorienting, psychedelic trip into the lives of drag queens in 1960s Tokyo. Well-known for having a heavy visual impact on Kubrick's "Clockwork Orange", come see one of the jewels of Japanese cinema

Free Pizza and drinks!
place: R.C. Mills Building- University Of Sydney

description:
This week, we're screening "Polyester". John Waters, the legendary king of trash cinema turns his eye towards the melodrama, creating the skewed story of a depressed housewife (plyaed by drag queen Divine, also star of Waters' "Pink Flamingos" and "Female Trouble"), her abusive pornographer husband and her two rebellious, criminal children. One of the most dysfunctional families ever captured on celluloid, "Polyester" is both bizarre and hillarious.

Free for filmsoc members, or only $5 to become a member for the entire year. Drinks and pizza will be provided
place: R.C. Mills Building- University Of Sydney

description:
We present F.W Murnau's silent masterpiece "Der letzte Mann". Considered one of the most silent silent films ever made, the film makes minimal use of intertitles and instead relies on the expressive power of lead actor Emil Jannings, a down on his luck former Doorman at a prestigious hotel. Komm runter!
Pizza and Drinks will be available!
place: R.C. Mills Building- University Of Sydney

event_name: Filmsoc presents: Picnic at Hanging Rock
description: Peter Weir's 1975 adaption of an Australian novel remains a treasure of Australian cinema. An intriguing mystery, the film remains enigmatic to the end, shot beautifully with graceful and languid cinematography from Russell Boyd
place: R.C. Mills Building- University Of Sydney

description: One of the best films of last year, Anna Biller's "The Love Witch" is a subversive feminst blend of Hitchock's 50/60s technicolour films, Jesus Franco's lascivious european exploitation films and a typical Witch narrative,  beautifully shot on vintage filmstock. One of the best-looking films in recent history, and also one of the most unique
place: R.C. Mills Building- University Of Sydney

description:
For our fourth screening, Filmsoc brings you Brian De Palma's bizarre musical masterpiece "Phantom of the Paradise": A rock opera loosely based around The Phantom of the Opera, wherein a musician is disfigured in a freak accident at a vinyl factory. With incredible music and a highly uncoventional story, this is not to be missed

Entry is FREE for Filmsoc members, $5 for non-members (who can join the society for $5 instead) and $11 for non-access card holders. There will also be free pizza and soft drink before the screening!

For our 3rd screening this semester, Filmsoc presents NZ directors Jane Campion's stellar 1993 drama "The Piano". Winner of the Palme d'Or, The Piano is a moving & haunting drama set in the 19th century, showing the story of a mute Scottish pianist and her daughter being married off and sailing to New Zealand. Incredibly shot along the beautiful backdrop of the New Zealand coastline, this is not to be missed
place: R.C. Mills Building- University Of Sydney

event_name: Filmsoc Week 2: Beyond The Valley of the Dolls
description:
Filmsoc's second screening is the American cult classic, "Beyond The Valley of the Dolls". Written by legendary film critic Roger Ebert and directed by notorious sexploitation auteur Russ Meyer, this film is ostensibly just a party movie about a young band, but it slowly reveals itself to be an intense and psychedelic satire of the original "Valley of the Dolls" and an incisive look at tail end of the psychedelic sixties that culminated in the Manson family murders. A must watch for anyone interested in cult psychedelic cinema

Free admission for Filmsoc members, $4 for non-Member Access card holders and $10 for non-Access card holders. Pizza and soft drinks provided free!

"Will ya have a drink?" Come join Filmsoc for a screening of an australian classic, Ted Kotcheff's "Wake in Fright". 
The film follows the story of a Sydney teacher stuck in a remote Outback town as he succumbs to the degeneracy of the townspeople. There will be plenty of free beer and pizza.

Screening is free for Filmsoc members, $4 for non-members with Access, and $10 for non-Access card holders OR $5 to become a Filmsoc member for the entire semester.
street: University of Sydney, Cnr City Rd & Butlin Ave Butlin Ave

description:
Dir. Peter Jackson - 1992 - New Zealand

Directed by a young Peter Jackson, BRAINDEAD is a thrilling horror-comedy. Braindead follows the naive Lionel (Timothy Balme), and his gory efforts to escape an overbearing mother, and to free a quiet New Zealand town from an infestation of the living dead. With plenty of laughs and buckets of blood, this splatterfest is sure to be a crowd-pleaser. As both our Halloween screening and our final event of the semester, we plan on celebrating in style, so there will popcorn and snacks on top of the usual pizza and soft drink.

***
Find us on Tuesday in Old Geology Lecture Theatre. We'll have pizza & snacks from 5pm and the screening will start at about 5:15pm. We'll be heading to the Forest Lodge Hotel afterwards for post-film drinks and discussion.

This event is free for members, $5 for Access cardholders. Annual membership is $5 for Access cardholders.

Dir. Guy Maddin - 2015 - Canada

The Forbidden Room is the latest film from Guy Maddin, whose My Winnipeg is a FilmSoc favourite. A submarine crew, a feared pack of forest bandits, a famous surgeon, and a battalion of child soldiers all get more than they bargained for as they wend their way toward progressive ideas on life and love. It's the funniest film Maddin has ever made, and its dreamlike aesthetic is exquisitely designed. Don't miss this one, it's a breathtaking experience.

***
Find us on Tuesday in Old Geology Lecture Theatre. We'll have pizza from 5pm and the screening will start at about 5:15pm. We'll be heading to the Forest Lodge Hotel afterwards for post-film drinks and discussion.

This event is free for members, $5 for Access cardholders. Annual membership is $5 for Access cardholders.

FilmSoc Trivia is back in Sem 2! Manning Bar will once again be hosting FilmSoc's night of nights.

We have prizes aplenty, including movies, tickets, posters, drink vouchers. The first place prize will be announced closer to the date, so keep your eyes peeled.

To make things a bit more personal, this year's FilmSoc executive will be hosting the evening. If all goes to plan, we'll also be adding an AV section for the big screen.

Teams are limited to 8 people. We'll run two big rounds, with separate games scattered throughout. Entry is free for Access members, $10 for non-Access!
street: Manning House, Manning Rd, University of Sydney

description:
Muddy River is the debut film of Kohei Oguri, a modern Japanese master. It was nominated for an Academy Award and despite it's limited reputation in the west it has been consistently listed as one of the greatest Japanese films of the 80s. It deals with topics familiar to fans of Kenji Mizoguchi and Yasujiro Ozu; prostitution, childhood, and human nature.

***
Find us on Tuesday in Old Geology Lecture Theatre. We'll have pizza from 5pm and the screening will start at about 5:15pm. We'll be heading to the Forest Lodge Hotel afterwards for post-film drinks and discussion.

This event is free for members, $5 for Access cardholders. Annual membership is $5 for Access cardholders.

Before this week's screening, FilmSoc will be holding its Annual General Meeting. We will be electing a brand new executive consisting of a President, Vice President, Secretary, Treasurer, Sponsorship Officer, Events Officers and 4x General Executives. All are welcome to nominate for the positions, you will simply be asked to speak briefly to your nomination.

If you can't make the meeting and want to nominate, message the FilmSoc account or email us at usydfilmsoc@gmail.com.

***
Dir. Jennie Livingstone - 1990 - USA

Right after we wrap up the AGM (~5:30pm) we'll start up this week's screening of Paris is Burning.  Paris is Burning is a monumental 1990 documentary tracing the poor, African American and Latino gay and transgendered community involved in the drag ball culture of New York City. It's a witty and moving doco, directed with profound empathy by Jennie Livingstone.

Dir. Kelly Reichardt - 2010 - USA

Directed by American indie filmmaker Kelly Reichardt, MEEK’S CUTOFF, follows a small group of settlers as they slowly make their way across the Oregon Trail in 1845. As the journey stretches on longer than anticipated, the group begins to lose faith in their stubborn hired guide and suspect that they are hopelessly lost.  Eschewing traditional notions of plot and drama, Reichardt opts instead for a naturalistic and understated approach, providing a deeply unsettling sense of uncertainty and desperation.

***
Find us on Tuesday in Old Geology Lecture Theatre. We'll have pizza from 5pm and the screening will start at about 5:15pm. We'll be heading to the Forest Lodge Hotel afterwards for post-film drinks and discussion.

This event is free for members, $5 for Access cardholders. Annual membership is $5 for Access cardholders.

Dir. Abbas Kiarostami - 2010 - Iran/France

Certified Copy is a phenomenal film from the late, great Iranian director Abbas Kiarostami. In Tuscany to promote his latest book, a middle-aged English writer meets a French woman who leads him to the village of Lucignano. It's an engrossing, strangely haunting film, with amazing performances to boot.

***
Find us on Tuesday in Old Geology Lecture Theatre. We'll have pizza from 5pm and the screening will start at about 5:15pm. We'll be heading to the Forest Lodge Hotel afterwards for post-film drinks and discussion.

This event is free for members, $5 for Access cardholders. Annual membership is $5 for Access cardholders.

Dir. John Hillcoat - 2005 - Australia

Written by Nick Cave, THE PROPOSITION is a dark and brutal gothic western, set in the Australian outback of the 1880s. Frustrated lawman Captain Stanley (Ray Winstone) manages to capture two members of the notorious Burns brothers gang. To the middle brother Charlie (Guy Pearce) he makes the following proposition: find and kill your older brother Arthur, or on Christmas day your younger brother will hang. The film launched the career of director John Hillcoat, and features a haunting score by Nick Cave and Warren Ellis. Harsh and uncompromising, we guarantee you have never seen a western quite like this before.

***
Find us on Tuesday in Old Geology Lecture Theatre. We'll have pizza from 5pm and the screening will start at about 5:15pm. We'll be heading to the Forest Lodge Hotel afterwards for post-film drinks and discussion.

This event is free for members, $5 for Access cardholders. Annual membership is $5 for Access cardholders.

event_name: FilmSoc Week 6: Sweet Smell of Success
description:
Dir. Alexander Mackendrick - 1957 - USA

In this stylish, satirical film noir, JJ Hunsecker, an infamous gossip columnist, and Sidney Falco, an unscrupulous, fast-talking press agent, lock horns as Hunsecker convinces Falco to break up his sister’s romance with a jazz musician.  Set in the glamorously scuzzy underworld of New York tabloid journalism, Sweet Smell of Success is a slick, cynical satire with wit to spare.

***

Find us on Tuesday in Old Geology Lecture Theatre. We'll have pizza from 5pm and the screening will start at about 5:15pm. We'll be heading to the Forest Lodge Hotel afterwards for post-film drinks and discussion.

This event is free for members, $5 for Access cardholders. Annual membership is $5 for Access cardholders.

event_name: FilmSoc + German Kultur Klub Present: M
description:
FilmSoc is teaming up with the German Kulture Klub to bring you one of the most critically acclaimed films of all time. Fritz Lang's Weimar masterpiece M is the story of a massive German manhunt for a serial killer who prays on children. It's a landmark thriller, groundbreaking in both storytelling and visuals, and a vital precursor to the serial killer and police procedural thrillers of the last hundred years.

***

We'll have extra snacks and drinks this week, courtesy of the GKK, with pizza and soft drink to boot.

Find us on Tuesday in Old Geology Lecture Theatre. We'll have food from 5pm and the screening will start at about 5:15pm. We'll be heading to the Forest Lodge Hotel afterwards for post-film drinks and discussion.

This event is free for members, $5 for Access cardholders. Annual membership is $5 for Access cardholders.

event_name: FilmSoc Week 4: Wild at Heart & General Meeting
description:
GENERAL MEETING
Before this week's screening, FilmSoc will be holding a General Meeting to elect a Vice President and Secretary. While these positions will be re-elected before the end of semester at the Annual General Meeting, it's a fantastic opportunity to get involved in FilmSoc (and get your foot in the door for next year). If you're interested, be there on the dot of 5pm. If you can't make it, send us a Facebook message and we can read out your nomination for you.

Right after the GM, we'll be screening David Lynch's bizarro cult classic WILD AT HEART
_______________________________________
Dir. David Lynch - 1990 - USA

WILD AT HEART stars Nic Cage and Laura Dern as Sailor and Lula, two young lovers who embark on a cross-country road trip, pursued by a rogues gallery of menacing weirdos that Lula’s mother has hired to kill Sailor.  The film won the Palme d’Or at the 1990 Cannes Film Festival and it was certainly a bold choice.  By turns hilarious and horrifying, with an on-point soundtrack, a colourful cast of characters, occasional references to the Wizard of Oz, and show-stopping performances delivered by Nicolas Cage and Laura Dern, this is David Lynch at his most flamboyantly strange and deliriously entertaining.  Oh, and if you’ve ever wanted to see Nic croon along to Elvis, then this is the movie for you.  Come along for a crime thriller-comedy-musical-road movie like no other.

***

Find us on Tuesday in Old Geology Lecture Theatre. We'll have pizza from 5pm and the screening will start at about 5:30pm. We'll be heading to the Forest Lodge Hotel afterwards for post-film drinks and discussion.

This event is free for members, $5 for Access cardholders. Annual membership is $5 for Access cardholders.

Dir. Thomas Vinterberg - 2012 - Denmark

One of Danish auteur Thomas Vinterberg’s most prestigious releases is THE HUNT (or JAGTEN), the compelling story of a man wrongly accused of sexually assaulting a child. The film was nominated for Best Foreign Language Film a few years back and Mads Mikkelsen (of Hannibal and Casino Royale fame in the US) took home a Cannes best actor award for his phenomenal performance as Lucas. It's a heart-breaking, nuanced film, and certainly not one you want to miss.

***

Find us on Tuesday in Old Geology Lecture Theatre. We'll have pizza from 5pm and the screening will start at about 5:15pm. We'll be heading to the Forest Lodge Hotel afterwards for post-film drinks and discussion.

This event is free for members, $5 for Access cardholders. Annual membership is $5 for Access cardholders.

event_name: FilmSoc Week 2: The Duke of Burgundy
description:
Dir. Peter Strickland - 2014 - UK

Festival favourite THE DUKE OF BURGUNDY is an enchanting portrait of a sensually and psychologically charged relationship between two women, Cynthia and Evelyn.  It's a film full of intriguing revelations, so we won't spoil anything further...  However, we can tell you that DUKE's impeccable, lush cinematography and its hauntingly lovely soundtrack make this a sensory experience to be remembered and revisited.

***

Join us at Old Geology Lecture Theatre for food and drink from 5pm! The screening will start at about 5:15pm. We'll be heading to the Forest Lodge Hotel afterwards for post-film drinks and discussion.

 This event is free for members, $5 for Access cardholders. Annual membership is $5 for Access cardholders.

Dir. Joe Dante, USA, 1984

Don't get them wet.  Don't expose them to bright light.  And whatever you do--don't feed them after midnight.

Semester Two is starting strong for FilmSoc with the greatest horror-comedy of them all: Gremlins! From director Joe Dante (The Howling, Piranha), Gremlins tells the story of a cute, fuzzy Christmas present that makes a terrifying transformation--with hilarious results. It's the perfect movie to watch with a crowd, and we'll have pizza, drinks and popcorn to boot.

We've relocated to the Old Geology Building this semester, where we'll have food and drink from 5pm. The screening will start at about 5:15pm. We'll be heading to the Forest Lodge Hotel afterwards for post-film drinks and discussion.

This event is free for members, $5 for Access cardholders. Annual membership is $5 for Access cardholders. You can sign up at Oday (where you can also pick up a sweet FilmSoc bag or shirt) or at the event. See you there!

Dir. Michael Arias, Japan, 2006

Capping off a screening list of visual delights is the much lauded (but criminally underseen) Japanese film Tekkonkinkreet—a hypnotic, kaleidoscopic animated experience from the makers of the Animatrix and adapted from the manga of the same name.

***

Find us on Tuesday in RC Mills Lecture Room 209. We'll have pizza from 5pm and the screening will start at about 5:15pm. We'll be heading to the Forest Lodge Hotel afterwards for post-film drinks and discussion.

This event is free for members, $5 for Access cardholders. Annual membership is $5 for Access cardholders.

Dir. Souleymane Cissé, Mali, 1987

We're capping off the semester with a few underseen visual treats. Souleymane Cissé's Yeelen is a completely unique Malian film set in the 13th Century. A hit at Cannes in 1987, Yeelen follows a young Bambara native, Niankoro, who leaves his mother’s house on a quest for spiritual enlightenment.

***

Find us on Tuesday in RC Mills Lecture Room 209. We'll have pizza from 5pm and the screening will start at about 5:15pm. We'll be heading to the Forest Lodge Hotel afterwards for post-film drinks and discussion.

This event is free for members, $5 for Access cardholders. Annual membership is $5 for Access cardholders.

event_name: FilmSoc Week 11: THE SPIRIT OF THE BEEHIVE
description:
Dir. Víctor Erice, Spain, 1973

Often considered the greatest Spanish film of the 1970s, El espíritu de la colmena takes place in a small Castilian village in 1940, not long after the Spanish Civil War. A traveling movie theatre screens the 1931 film "Frankenstein" for the village, and seven-year old Ana (Ana Torrent) is haunted by the scene in which a young girl is drowned. Anchored by the unforgettably solemn yet curious gaze of its young star, the film is enigmatic, bewitching, visually arresting, and rich in symbolism.

***

Find us on Tuesday in RC Mills Lecture Room 209. We'll have pizza from 5pm and the screening will start at about 5:15pm. We'll be heading to the Forest Lodge Hotel afterwards for post-film drinks and discussion.

This event is free for members, $5 for Access cardholders. Annual membership is $5 for Access cardholders.

Dir. Miranda July, USA, 2011

This week we're checking out writer/director/actor Miranda July's second feature, The Future.  July brings her offbeat brand of comedy to this tale of a couple of hapless thirty-somethings who attempt to adopt a stray cat.  Though wondrous and whimsical on its surface, there is a great deal of emotional nuance and dark humour to be found in this observation of modern relationships.

***

Find us on Tuesday in RC Mills Lecture Room 209. We'll have pizza from 5pm and the screening will start at about 5:15pm. We'll be heading to the Forest Lodge Hotel afterwards for post-film drinks and discussion.

This event is free for members, $5 for Access cardholders. Annual membership is $5 for Access cardholders.

Dir. Nicholas Roeg, 1971, Australia/UK

The film that made David Gulpilil the icon he remains today, Walkabout follows two young siblings stranded in the Australian Outback. They meet an Indigenous boy (played by Gulpilil) on walkabout who saves their lives and shows them how to survive.

This beautifully shot film, the second by Nicolas Roeg, and has become one of the most iconic Australian films (despite its British director) and one of the more progressive and realistic representations of the Australian outback. It's not one you want to miss.

***

Find us on Tuesday in RC Mills Lecture Room 209. We'll have pizza from 5pm and the screening will start at about 5:15pm. We'll be heading to the Forest Lodge Hotel afterwards for post-film drinks and discussion.

This event is free for members, $5 for Access cardholders. Annual membership is $5 for Access cardholders.

Dir. The Wachowskis, USA, 2008

The Wachowskis first directorial effort after The Matrix Trilogy was the weird and wonderful Speed Racer. An adaptation of a much-loved Japanese manga and anime, the movie was a critical and commercial bomb, but, eight years later, is now a budding cult film, layered with political allegory and creativity. A multi-coloured, multi-dimensional gem, Speed Racer changed the FX game. So put aside your initial skepticism and give it a go.

***

Find us on Tuesday in RC Mills Lecture Room 209. We'll have pizza from 5pm and the screening will start at about 5:15pm. We'll be heading to the Forest Lodge Hotel afterwards for post-film drinks and discussion.

This event is free for members, $5 for Access cardholders. Annual membership is $5 for Access cardholders.

FilmSoc Trivia is back in 2016! Join us at Manning Bar for one of the highlights of the FilmSoc calendar.

We have prizes aplenty--movies, tickets, posters, drink vouchers--so play to win. And if you don't, you'll probably still walk away with a Jean-Claude Van Damme Blu Ray, which is a victory in itself.

Friend of the society, Film Studies faculty member and trash cinephile Josh Wheatley will be hosting the evening.

Teams are limited to 8 people. We'll run two big rounds over two and a bit hours, with separate games scattered throughout. Entry is free for Access members, $10 for non-Access!
street: Manning House, Manning Rd, University of Sydney

description:
Dir. Stanley Kubrick, 1955, USA

THE KILLING may be one of the lesser-seen films in Stanley Kubrick's illustrious oeuvre, but it is also easily one of the most entertaining.  It's a heist film, following a group of ex-cons who develop a meticulous plan to rob a racetrack. But as the scheme is set into motion, it starts to look like their best-laid plans might not be as watertight as they thought. With whip-smart, rapidfire dialogue, a twisty, time-hopping plot and slick film noir touches, THE KILLING is a stylish and thrilling bit of genre fun.

***

Find us on Tuesday in RC Mills Lecture Room 209. We'll have pizza from 5pm and the screening will start at about 5:15pm. We'll be heading to the Forest Lodge Hotel afterwards for post-film drinks and discussion.

This event is free for members, $5 for Access cardholders. Annual membership is $5 for Access cardholders.

event_name: FilmSoc Week 6: BATTLES WITHOUT HONOUR AND HUMANITY
description:
Directed by Kinji Fukasaku--most famous in the west for Battle Royale--Battles Without Honour and Humanity is widely considered the “Japanese Godfather”, albeit with a hell of a lot more violence. Chronicling the underworld tribulations of a young ex-soldier and street thug in post-war Hiroshima, this is an intensely engaging and provocative Yakuza film.

***

Find us on Tuesday in RC Mills Lecture Room 209. We'll have pizza from 5pm and the screening will start at about 5:15pm. We'll be heading to the Forest Lodge Hotel afterwards for post-film drinks and discussion.

This event is free for members, $5 for Access cardholders. Annual membership is $5 for Access cardholders.

The first feature film shot entirely in Saudi Arabia and the first feature-length film made by a female Saudi director, Wadjda is the simple and brave debut by Haifaa al-Mansour, which played the Sydney Film Festival to much acclaim back in 2013.

Telling the story of a young Saudi Arabian girl who dreams of owning a green bicycle that she passes in a store every day on her way to school, Wadjda features fascinating social commentary complemented by a tremendous lead performance and clever writing.

***

Find us on Tuesday in RC Mills Lecture Room 209. We'll have pizza from 5pm and the screening will start at about 5:15pm. We'll be heading to the Forest Lodge Hotel afterwards for post-film drinks and discussion.

This event is free for members, $5 for Access cardholders. Annual membership is $5 for Access cardholders.

Our next screening will be the Spike Lee-directed 25th Hour. Powerful, moving, and widely considered one of the best American films of the 2000s, 25th Hour looks at post-9/11 NYC through the story of a man preparing to go to prison for selling drugs. It's an unforgettable film and its impact has only developed with time.

Find us on Tuesday in RC Mills Lecture Room 209. We'll have pizza from 5pm and the screening will start at about 5:15pm. We'll be heading to the Forest Lodge Hotel afterwards for post-film drinks and discussion.

This event is free for FilmSoc members, $5 for Access cardholders. Annual membership is $5 for Access cardholders.

event_name: FilmSoc Week 3: THE ACT OF KILLING
description:
Join us in Week 3 for one of the most acclaimed documentaries of all time. The Act of Killing exposes the horrifying mass executions of accused communists in Indonesia and those who are celebrated in their country for perpetrating the crime.

Find us on Tuesday in RC Mills Lecture Room 209. We'll have pizza from 5pm and the screening will start at about 5:15pm. We'll be heading to the Forest Lodge Hotel afterwards for post-film drinks and discussion.

This event is free for members, $5 for Access cardholders. Annual membership is $5 for Access cardholders.

event_name: FilmSoc Welcome Drinks at The Flodge
description:
Hey FilmSoccers!  This Tuesday we'll be having a meet n greet at our favourite movie-postered pub, The Forest Lodge Hotel (aka the Flodge) to welcome you all into a new year of FilmSoc festivities.  Swing by any time from 4.30pm to mingle with some fellow film-lovers, share a few drinks, and sample some fine pub food (Flodge fries are a must).  Drinks, pizza and fries are on us!

This event is free for FilmSoc members, $5 for other Access card holders and $9 for non-Access.  FilmSoc membership is $5 for Access cardholders.

event_name: FilmSoc Opening Night: AMERICAN PSYCHO at Hermanns
description:
“I have to return some videotapes.” — Patrick Bateman, American Psycho

Welcome to FilmSoc for 2016.

We’re kicking off the year by spending a few days in the cap-toe leather shoes of Manhattan businessman-cum-psychopath Patrick Bateman. Adapted from Brett Easton Ellis’ infamous novel, American Psycho went criminally underappreciated in 1999 but has since lingered in the minds of sadists and cult aficionados alike. Led by a chilling yet hilarious performance by Christian Bale, this subversive horror-comedy is a must-see portrait of 80’s excess.

The screening will be held at Hermann's Bar from 7pm on Thursday during week 1. Entry is free for Access cardholders and $10 for non-access. You can sign up to be a member at the FilmSoc stall during Oweek or on the night. All are welcome to free pizza and a drink voucher.
street: University of Sydney, Cnr City Rd & Butlin Ave Butlin Ave

description:
FilmSoc continues its annual tradition, celebrating Halloween with a mystery movie specially chosen by the exec—you won't know what hits you until it does!  Bring your friends and a brave face. 

Find us on Wednesday in the Old Geology Lecture Theatre! We'll have pizza from 5pm and the screening will start at 5:15pm. We'll be heading to the Forest Lodge Hotel afterwards for post-film drinks and discussion.

Dir. William Greaves - 1968 - USA

Ever wondered what a documentary about a documentary about the production of a fake narrative film looks like?  Well fear no more, because the perplexingly-titled Symbiopsychotaxiplasm is exactly that: a sharp and provocative expose of filmmaking and its ethics.

Find us on Wednesday in the Old Geology Lecture Theatre! We'll have pizza from 5pm and the screening will start at 5:15pm. We'll be heading to the Forest Lodge Hotel afterwards for post-film drinks and discussion.

event_name: FilmSoc and SUFF present: SECRET CINEMA #4
description:
FilmSoc and Sydney Underground Film Festival present Secret Cinema, 5 nights of cinema from around the outer fringes of Hollywood and beyond.

The next one will be held on Thursday 15th October in the Balmain area (location revealed the day before the event). We can't tell you the film, it's a secret. But we can tell you, it's going to be a surprise, and not for the faint hearted. No rom-coms here!

Doors open from 6:30pm. Film at 8:30pm. 

Previous events have been held in secret warehouses, rooftops and alleyways. The next secret cinema will be huge! Alongside the film will be live performances, bands, and complimentary food and drinks. The cheapest night out in Sydney. Don't miss out.  Reserve your tickets here: https://www.eventbrite.com.au/e/secret-cinema-screening-4-tickets-18815200772

Claire Munro AKA Klayer Sslayer, SUFF's artist set designer, will cook up another mini exhibition based on the chosen film.

Dir. Larisa Sheptiko - 1977 - USSR

This week we’re taking a darker turn with The Ascent, a WWII-set Soviet war drama.  Shot in crisp black-and-white, Larisa Shepitko’s final film is a harrowing and beautifully poetic interrogation of the moral dilemmas of wartime.

Find us on Wednesday in the Old Geology Lecture Theatre! We'll have pizza from 5pm and the screening will start at 5:15pm. We'll be heading to the Forest Lodge Hotel afterwards for post-film drinks and discussion.

FREE for members: $5 for Access cardholders. Annual membership is $5 for Access cardholders!

Dir. Paul Verhoeven - 1997 - USA

The films of Paul Verhoeven ('Robocop', 'Showgirls') often combine viciously ironic satire with outrageous excess, and 'Starship Troopers' is no exception.  Undoubtedly an entertainingly campy spectacle (featuring all the space-bug-related carnage you could hope for), 'Starship Troopers' also showcases Verhoeven's flair for biting cultural critique.

Find us on Wednesday in the Old Geology Lecture Theatre! We'll have pizza from 5pm and the screening will start at 5:15pm. We'll be heading to the Forest Lodge Hotel afterwards for post-film drinks and discussion.

FREE for members: $5 for Access cardholders. Annual membership is $5 for Access cardholders!

Avoid mid-sem FilmSoc withdrawals and come along with us to see 'Showgirls'!

The University is hosting a screening and symposium to commemorate the 20th anniversary of this infamous cult classic.  The day will start from 10am in Old Geology Lecture Theatre with a screening of the film, which will be followed by a series of academic talks.

Once dismissed as one of the worst films of all time, Paul Verhoeven's erotic drama 'Showgirls' has made a comeback in recent years and is now held by some to be contemporary masterpiece.  Love it or loathe it, this is a pretty essential movie experience.  Plus, it'll make a great prelude to our screening of Starship Troopers (also directed by Paul Verhoeven) in Week 10!

Entry is free and all are welcome to attend.  See you there!

FilmSoc and Sydney Underground Film Festival present Secret Cinema, 5 nights of cinema from around the outer fringes of Hollywood and beyond.

Our third screening is coming up this Friday, 25 September.  Location is TBA - stay tuned.  And of course, we can't tell you the film, but rest assured you'll be in for another memorable, one-of-a-kind experience that is not for the faint-of-heart!

Entry to the event is FREE and nibblies and beverages will be provided.

In this classic of 90s American independent cinema, Julianne Moore (in her first major film role) plays a housewife suddenly beset by a strange, seemingly inexplicable illness. A film that finds unsettling weirdness in ostensibly innocuous places, Safe offers an intriguing and hypnotic film experience.

Find us on Wednesday in the Old Geology Lecture Theatre!  We're having our Annual General Meeting (https://www.facebook.com/events/681586765274791/) and pizza from 5pm before the screening. We'll be heading to the Forest Lodge Hotel afterwards for post-film drinks and discussion.

FREE for members: $5 for Access cardholders. Annual membership is $5 for Access cardholders!

Join us for FilmSoc's AGM, where we'll be recapping the last year of FilmSoc and, most importantly, electing the new executive team for 2016.

The following positions will be up for election:
- President
- Vice-President
- Secretary
- Treasurer
- Events Officer
- Sponsorship Officer
- 4 x General executives

More info about the elections to come.

There will be pizza from 5pm as usual.  Stick around after the meeting for our screening of "Safe"!

The films of Swedish director Roy Andersson have often been described as combining the existential angst of Ingmar Bergman, the meticulous visual sensibility of Jacques Tati and the absurd humour of Monty Python. While these comparisons don't do justice to the striking uniqueness of his work, they might give you some idea of what to expect from this film. Come along and see for yourself why Andersson has become a festival favourite.

Find us on Wednesday in the Old Geology Lecture Theatre! We'll have pizza from 5pm and the screening will start at 5:15pm. We'll be heading to the Forest Lodge Hotel afterwards for post-film drinks and discussion.

FREE for members: $5 for Access cardholders. Annual membership is $5 for Access cardholders!

Stories told through the eyes of precocious children often blend earnest innocence with strange fantasies of a hyperbolic imagination. Saura plays with this perspective to remarkable effect in this film set in post-Franco Spain, where a family and its political environment deteriorate in tandem. Surreal hallucinatory interludes laced through the film's otherwise prosaic plot make this a quietly haunting experience.

Find us on Wednesday in the Old Geology Lecture Theatre! We'll have pizza from 5pm and the screening will start at 5:15pm. We'll be heading to the Forest Lodge Hotel afterwards for post-film drinks and discussion.

FREE for members: $5 for Access cardholders. Annual membership is $5 for Access cardholders!

This anime from the great Satoshi Kon ('Perfect Blue','Paprika') intertwines a heartfelt tale of lost love with an epic, mind-bending journey through the history of Japanese cinema. Surely one of the most enchanting and incredibly inventive animated films you're ever likely to see.

Find us on Wednesday in the Old Geology Lecture Theatre! We'll have pizza from 5pm and the screening will start at 5:15pm. We'll be heading to the Forest Lodge Hotel afterwards for post-film drinks and discussion.

FREE for members: $5 for Access cardholders. Annual membership is $5 for Access cardholders!

event_name: Filmsoc Week 5: A GIRL WALKS HOME ALONE AT NIGHT
description:
Ana Lily Amirpour directs the "first Iranian vampire Western" in A Girl Walks Home Alone At Night. A solitary vampire lurks the streets of Bad City, Iran, unbeknownst to its gloomy citizens. A haunting debut by Amirpour that blends genres from spaghetti Western to Iranian New Wave.

Find us on Wednesday in the Old Geology Lecture Theatre! We'll have pizza from 5pm and the screening will start at 5:15pm. We'll be heading to the Forest Lodge Hotel afterwards for post-film drinks and discussion.

FREE for members: $5 for Access cardholders. Annual membership is $5 for Access cardholders!

FilmSoc and Sydney Underground Film Festival present Secret Cinema, 5 nights of cinema from around the outer fringes of Hollywood and beyond.
 
The first of these screenings is coming up this Saturday, 22 August.  We'll be meeting at Marrickville Bowling Club from 5pm, after which you'll be escorted to a nearby secret location for a 6pm start.

Of course, we can't tell you the film, but rest assured you'll be in for a memorable, one-of-a-kind experience that is not for the faint-of-heart!

Entry to the event is FREE and nibblies and beverages will be provided.

Register your tickets: https://www.eventbrite.com.au/e/secret-cinema-screening-1-tickets-18161963923

event_name: Filmsoc and the French Society present: LES DIABOLIQUES
description:
This week Filmsoc and the University of Sydney French Society have joined forces to present Les Diaboliques. Preceding and inspiring many of the early classics of psychological horror (such as Hitchcock's Psycho), Les Diaboliques is a wicked tale set in a boarding school in provincial France. Even today, it remains a powerfully suspenseful and creepy film with an unforgettable ending.

Find us on Wednesday in the Old Geology Lecture Theatre! We'll have super special French pastries from La Banette from 5pm and the screening will start at 5:15pm. We'll be heading to the Forest Lodge Hotel afterwards for post-film drinks and discussion.

FREE for members: $5 for Access cardholders. Annual membership is $5 for Access cardholders!

Jodorowsky's Dune is the story of one of the greatest sci-fi films never made: the attempt in the mid 1970s by cult maverick director Alejandro Jodorowsky to adapt Frank Herbert's 1965 novel 'Dune'. This often hilarious documentary gives insight into Jodorowsky's imaginative and bizarre version of 'Dune', and reveals the surprising legacy that the failed project has left for contemporary sci-fi cinema.

Find us on Wednesday in the Old Geology Lecture Theatre! We'll have pizza and drinks from 5pm and the screening will start at 5:15pm. We'll be heading to the Forest Lodge Hotel afterwards for post-film drinks and discussion.

FREE for members: $5 for Access cardholders. Annual membership is $5 for Access cardholders!

If you’re curious to see Martin Scorsese taking on a full-blown madcap comedy, come check out After Hours.  Taking place over the course of one Kafka-esque night in New York City, After Hours is an increasingly hyperactive farce, distinguished by its dark, surreal humour, and bold visual style.

Find us on Wednesday in the Old Geology Lecture Theatre! We'll have pizza and drinks from 5pm and the screening will start at 5:15pm. We'll be heading to the Forest Lodge Hotel afterwards for post-film drinks and discussion.

FREE for members: $5 for Access cardholders. Annual membership is $5 for Access cardholders!

event_name: Filmsoc Opening Night: MAD MAX: THE ROAD WARRIOR
description:
Filmsoc is kicking off semester two with the Australian action classic ‘Mad Max: The Road Warrior’. Directed by George Miller ('Mad Max: Fury Road', 'Happy Feet'), 'The Road Warrior' follows a cynical drifter (Mel Gibson),as he defends a besieged community from a gang of leather-bound barbarians in a post-apocalyptic Australia.

Find us on Wednesday in the Old Geology Lecture Theatre! We'll have pizza and drinks from 5pm and the screening will start at 5:15pm. We'll be heading to the Forest Lodge Hotel afterwards for post-film drinks and discussion.

FREE for members: $5 for Access cardholders. Annual membership is $5 for Access cardholders!

Shane Carruth, of "Primer" fame, directs, writes, stars in, and composes the score of the surreal "Upstream Color". It's an unforgettable film reminiscent of top-end Malick in both its visual appeal and poetic rhythm. FilmSoc will be hosting the screening of "Upstream Color" alongside the Sydney-based film site 4:3, in what will surely be one of the highlights of the FilmSoc calendar.

Find us on Wednesday in the Quad History Room S223! We'll have pizza and drinks from 5pm and the screening will start at 5:15pm. We'll be heading to the Forest Lodge Hotel afterwards for post-film drinks and discussion.

FREE for members: $5 for Access cardholders. Annual membership is $5 for Access cardholders!

event_name: Filmsoc Week 12: Pastoral: To Die in the Country
description:
A surreal coming-of-age film, set in an indeterminate rural village in Japan flushed with intoxicating colour, accompanied by superstitious rituals and a destructively dysfunctional circus. Towards the middle of his career, Terayama adopts a more topical and less experimental film-making approach, yet maintains his distinctive, uncompromising personal aesthetic.

Find us on Wednesday in the Quad History Room S223! We'll have pizza and drinks from 5pm and the screening will start at 5:15pm. We'll be heading to the Forest Lodge Hotel afterwards for post-film drinks and discussion.

FREE for members: $5 for Access cardholders. Annual membership is $5 for Access cardholders!

event_name: Filmsoc Week 11: 4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days
description:
In Cristian Mungiu's Palme d'Or-winning masterpiece, the clash between personal autonomy and government interference goes under the microscope. An almost real-time film about abortion, communism, companionship and sacrifice, "4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days" is the pinnacle of Romanian New Wave realism.

Find us on Wednesday in the Quad History Room S223! We'll have pizza and drinks from 5pm and the screening will start at 5:15pm. We'll be heading to the Forest Lodge Hotel afterwards for post-film drinks and discussion.

FREE for members: $5 for Access cardholders. Annual membership is $5 for Access cardholders!

UPDATE: This year's special guest will be BRENDAN COWELL, the writer/director of opening night film Ruben Guthrie.

FilmSoc and the Film Studies Department are proud to be hosting a special preview of the offerings at this years Sydney Film Festival, presented by Festival director Nashen Moodley. The Sydney Film Festival Showcase will feature advance previews of major films premiering at the festival, as well as an address by Director Moodley about the Festival and how to get involved.

Other speakers will include a featured filmmaker who will talk about his work, and a student intern from the University of Sydney who will discuss their involvement with the Festival. There will also be information about filmmaking courses at Sydney University.

Come along and enjoy this opportunity to hear about and involve yourself in the rich film culture on offer during the festival.

This week we're checking out Sam Raimi's infamous, hilarious 80s schlockfest, Evil Dead II.  While its predecessor was a cult horror classic in its own right, Evil Dead II amps up the comedy to deliver one of the most memorable "cabin in the woods" movies you're ever likely to see.  It's gory, demented and a whole lot of fun.  Cheers to whoever suggested this in our Audience Choice poll last week!

Find us on Wednesday in the Quad History Room S223! We'll have pizza and drinks from 5pm and the screening will start at 5:15pm. We'll be heading to the Forest Lodge Hotel afterwards for post-film drinks and discussion.

FREE for members: $5 for Access cardholders. Annual membership is $5 for Access cardholders!

Spanish film Timecrimes is a time travel flick described aptly by the late Roger Ebert as a "temporal chess game with nudity, voyeurism and violence". It's all that and more, despite a relatively tiny budget. Our second foray into genre this semester is probably also the most fun you'll have all semester, so don't miss it.

Find us on Wednesday in the Quad History Room S223! We'll have pizza and drinks from 5pm and the screening will start at 5:15pm. We'll be heading to the Forest Lodge Hotel afterwards for post-film drinks and discussion.

FREE for members: $5 for Access cardholders. Annual membership is $5 for Access cardholders!

event_name: Filmsoc Week 8: Meshes of the Afternoon/Le Bonheur
description:
Note: We will be screening Meshes of the Afternoon immediately before our feature screening for the week, Le Bonheur.

One of the most influential short films ever made, Meshes of the Afternoon simultaneously makes perfect sense, and is completely ambiguous. Surrealistic and bleak, Maya Deren expresses her unique feminist perspective through a variety of stylistic innovations.

In Le Bonheur, Agnès Varda zeroes in on the apparently idyllic existence of a French family. Though simple and sunny on its surface, this classic of the French New Wave ditches moralistic clichés in favour of a more complex and idiosyncratic reflection on the pursuit of happiness ("le bonheur") in modern relationships.

Find us on Wednesday in the Quad History Room S223! We'll have pizza and drinks from 5pm and the screening will start at 5:15pm. We'll be heading to the Forest Lodge Hotel afterwards for post-film drinks and discussion.

FREE for members: $5 for Access cardholders. Annual membership is $5 for Access cardholders!

In 2003, in between "Dancer in the Dark" and "Dogville", Danish provocateur Lars von Trier released his most structurally experimental film in "The Five Obstructions". The documentary follows von Trier as he challenges his friend and film mentor, Jørgen Leth to remake Leth's short film "The Perfect Human" five times, each with a different 'obstruction' imposed. The obstructions vary from location, to form, and to cast - each offer fascinating variations of an underappreciated film by a criminally underappreciated filmmaker.

Find us on Wednesday in the Quad History Room S223! We'll have pizza and drinks from 5pm and the screening will start at 5:15pm. We'll be heading to the Forest Lodge Hotel afterwards for post-film drinks and discussion.

FREE for members: $5 for Access cardholders. Annual membership is $5 for Access cardholders!

What would you do if you could get a second chance at life? Such is the tantalising premise of Seconds, a thriller whose eerie and unsettling atmosphere will stick with you for days. Striking for its nightmarish editing and cinematography, and raising some troubling questions about freedom, happiness and identity, Seconds is a particularly daring example of classic Hollywood cinema.

Find us on Wednesday in the Quad History Room S223! We'll have pizza and drinks from 5pm and the screening will start at 5:15pm. We'll be heading to the Forest Lodge Hotel afterwards for post-film drinks and discussion.

FREE for members: $5 for Access cardholders. Annual membership is $5 for Access cardholders!

Remember when Filmsoc hosted an awesome trivia night during Oweek? Well, if you still know your Birdmen from your Third Men, join us for our second trivia night of Semester 1 on Tuesday 31st at Manning Bar!

We have tonnes of movies, tickets, posters, drink vouchers and other fun stuff to give away as prizes. So play to win (or come second last).

Entry is free for Access members, $10 for non-Access! Teams are limited to 6 people.
street: Manning House, Manning Rd, University of Sydney

event_name: Filmsoc Week 4: WALTZ WITH BASHIR + General Meeting
description:
Come for quorum, stay for pizza.

Digital animation is used to astounding effect in Ari Folman's docudrama of the Sabra and Chatila massacres in the 1982 Lebanese War. This dream-like meditation on collective memory and national trauma presents these tragedies in an unforgettably hypnotic way.

This week Filmsoc will be holding a General Meeting prior to its screening of Waltz with Bashir - come by at 5 for the short meeting or at 5:30 for the film screening on Wednesday in the Quad History Room S223! We'll be heading to the Forest Lodge Hotel afterwards for post-film drinks and discussion.

FREE for members: $5 for Access cardholders. Annual membership is $5 for Access cardholders!

You can’t get rid of the Babadook.

Stephen King said, "You don't watch it so much as experience it". Jennifer Kent's debut feature film is a chilling psychological - and slightly Freudian - study of a mother and her son as they match wits with a fictional monster that seems all too real. No stone is left unturned in creating a haunting sensory experience: from the intimate sound design to Noah Wiseman's disturbingly deft portrayal of protagonist Amelia's son Samuel. If you missed The Babadook in cinemas - and you probably did in its feeble, 13-screen Australian release - now's your chance to see the film that Peter Bradshaw said "leaves behind it a satisfyingly toxic residue of fear".

Find us on Wednesday in the Quad History Room S223! We'll have pizza and drinks from 5pm and the screening will start at 5:15pm. We'll be heading to the Forest Lodge Hotel afterwards for post-film drinks and discussion.

FREE for members: $5 for Access cardholders. Annual membership is $5 for Access cardholders!

event_name: FilmSoc Week 2: DO THE RIGHT THING
description:
Can’t stand the heat? Nor can Spike Lee. With DO THE RIGHT THING, Lee presents an incredibly nuanced interrogation of contemporary race relations that is as humorous, dynamic and colourful as it is troubling.  A conversation-starter if there ever was one, DO THE RIGHT THING remains as compelling and relevant as it was in 1989.

Come see it with us in our new home, Quad History Room S223!  There will be pizza and drinks from 5pm and the screening will start at 5:15pm.  We'll be heading to the Forest Lodge Hotel afterwards for post-film drinks and discussion.

Free for members - $5 for other Access cardholders.   Annual membership is $5 and requires an Access card.

event_name: FilmSoc Opening Night: FARGO at Hermann's!
description:
￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼Welcome to FilmSoc for 2015. With FX's popular anthology show, Fargo, about to enter its second season, it's high time we all revisit the film that inspired it.

Often remembered for the quirky Midwesternisms of its characters ("Yah? Oh jeez."), this oddball neo-noir crime comedy from the Coen brothers is beloved by many a movie buff thanks to its alchemic blend of comedy, violence and bleak absurdity. Directed with unfaltering panache and populated by a cast boasting some of America's best character actors (see: Frances McDormand, William H Macy, Steve Buscemi), Fargo is an inspired and hugely entertaining movie by two of the most important filmmakers working today. Darn tootin'.

This opening screening will be held at Hermann's Bar from 7pm on Monday, week 1. 

Entry is free for Access cardholders and $10 for non-access. All attendees will receive free pizza and a drink voucher.
street: University of Sydney, Cnr City Rd & Butlin Ave Butlin Ave

description:
Know your McFlys from your McQueens? Your Birdmen from your Third Men? Join FilmSoc for it’s first event of the year: 2 hours of high intensity film trivia for beginners and buffs alike.

Hosted by THE Jack Gow.

We also have tonnes of movies, tickets, posters, drink vouchers and other fun stuff we're looking to give away as prizes. So play to win (or come second last).

Entry is free & teams of up to 6.
street: Manning House, Manning Rd, University of Sydney

description:
This year we're doing something a little different for our last film of the semester. In celebration of Halloween we're going to be showing a scary movie, but there's a catch: we're not going to tell you what it is. 

What we can tell you is that it’s a film that'll get way inside your head where it'll likely stay for weeks. Come along. But wear your cheapest chinos. You’ve been warned.

There will be popcorn, drinks and pizza.

Old Geology, 5pm. See you there.

dir. Apichatpong Weersasethakul - 2004 - Thailand

FilmSoc screened Apichatpong Weerasethakul’s masterpiece Uncle Boonmee Who Can Recall Past Lives as our final film last year, though it has often been considered inferior to the more personal, intimate and innovative Tropical Malady, which Weerasethakul released 10 years ago.

Tropical Malady evokes the same trademark surrealism as the filmmakers later works, however, it is more reflective of Weerasethakul’s background as an experimental queer filmmaker, as well as well as his relationship with his Thai heritage and culture. Tropical Malady is a very rare film, and without a doubt one of the most important films of the last ten years.

***
Food and drinks in Old Geo from 5, screening will start at 5:15 - see ya there.

dir. Yasujiro Ozu - 1949 - Japan

Bar TOKYO STORY, LATE SPRING is perhaps Yasujiro Ozu’s most prominent work. The film also stars Setsuko Hara - often regarded as the most important actress of Ozu’s era - in one of her definitive roles. The film is a slow-moving, typical Ozu film, however, it is one that works on perfecting these ‘trademark’ characteristics, with LATE SPRING emerging as one of Ozu’s most critically lauded works to date. Arguably Japan’s most influential filmmaker, Ozu’s LATE SPRING is essential viewing as an entry point into the incredibly intricate and broad film landscape that is Japanese cinema.

We'll be meeting in Old Geo once again at 5 for food and drinks, with the screening starting at 5:15

event_name: FilmSoc Week 10: TO BE OR NOT TO BE
description:
dir. Ernst Lubitsch - 1942 - USA

We’re back from our brief hiatus with this classic screwball comedy, directed by the master of American screwball, Ernst Lubitsch.  Set in Nazi-occupied Poland during WWII, the film revolves around a troupe of Polish actors who are swept up in a plot to prevent a German spy from delivering a potentially catastrophic message to the enemy.  Madness ensues.  From its surprisingly bold approach to its then-topical subject matter (the film was made and released while the war was in full swing) to its sharp, energetic blend of comedy, romance, suspense, and satire, this is a remarkable and wholly delightful film.

As usual, food and drinks from 5pm, screening at 5:15pm, pub banter and revelry after the screening.

N.B. For this week only, FilmSoc's Annual General Meeting will be held from 5pm and the screening will begin once the meeting is finished.  There will be pizza and drinks at the meeting, where FilmSoc's members will elect the new executive for 2015.  https://www.facebook.com/events/704636859614483/?fref=ts

***DESCRIPTION***
dir. Claire Denis - 2008 - France

Claire Denis is one of the pre-eminent figures of contemporary world cinema, with films concerned with family and relationships as well as cross-cultural tensions, stemming from her colonial African background which informs her work.

35 Shots of Rum is arguably her masterpiece, and perhaps the best example of her work as associated with that nebulous term of ‘contemplative cinema’ – films of great subtlety, long take aesthetic, mood and showing rather than telling – and the most obvious nod to Yasujiro Ozu, the great master that is perhaps her greatest influence, in its ostensible reworking of Late Spring (which we are screening in Week 11). The masterfully woven tale of a father and daughter’s changing relationship is both simple in plot and expansive and affecting in its implications and feeling, an instant classic of French cinema.

It's that time of year again when FilmSoc's members gather together to reminisce over the semesters gone by and to democratically decide who will be running the society in 2015.  If you want to be more involved with Sydney's biggest and best student film society, then we'd love to see you put your hand up for one of the available exec positions.

POSITIONS TO BE ELECTED, in the following order: 
-President
-Vice-President
-Secretary
-Treasurer
-Events Officer
-Sponsorship Officer
-4 x General Executive

Full agenda and details on what each position involves will be issued shortly.

Bear in mind that you can nominate yourself for more than one position, but if you are elected to one of the positions, you cannot run for the subsequent ones.  (e.g. if you nominate for Secretary, but you don't win that round, then you can still nominate for any of the subsequent positions. However, if your nomination is successful, you can't then run to be an Events Officer, and so on.)

Also, if you can't come to the meeting, don't worry: you can submit your nomination in advance by sending us an email (usydfilmsoc@gmail.com) with your name, Access card number, and the position(s) you are nominating for.
You can also send us a few words about why you'd be a good fit for that position/why you'd like to be more involved with FilmSoc/any ideas that you have for the society that we can read to the meeting in your absence (optional).

After the meeting, we'll be holding our screening of 35 SHOTS OF RUM, along with pizza and drinks as usual.

dir. Dee Rees - 2011 - USA

PARIAH focuses on a 17-year-old African American girl called Alike who lives in Brooklyn and who comes to terms with and embraces her sexuality.  It’s as much about expression as it is repression, and while it’s co-funded by Spike Lee, it’s written and directed by first-time filmmaker Dee Rees, whose story Alike’s is inspired by. Come along to Old Geo at 5 this Wednesday to see a film that broaches intersectional issues of race, gender and sexuality with nuance and charm.

Food and drinks will be had from 5pm and the screening will start at 5:15pm.

event_name: FilmSoc Week 7: The Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie
description:
dir. Luis Bunuel - 1972 - France/Spain

With THE DISCREET CHARM OF THE BOURGEOISIE, Luis Bunuel transforms the sacrosanct bourgeois ritual of dinner into a platform for social critique. Surreal and satirical in equal measure, watch society's upper crust devolve into chaos as plans for a dinner party are thwarted time and time again, with each incident becoming more ludicrous than the last.  Despite completely eschewing logic and plot, it's a unique experience that somehow remains utterly enthralling and highly enjoyable.

VENUE CHANGE:  Instead of our usual venue, this week's screening will be held in the Common Room of the Woolley Building (Room N480).  We'll be meeting there at 5pm for food and drinks, then starting the film at 5:15pm.  Hope to see you there for this surrealist classic!
place: N480 Woolley Common Room, John Woolley Building

description:
dir. Abbas Kiarostami - 1990 - Iran

Close-Up has got to be one of the most dazzling films to emerge from the Iranian New Wave, a movement known for films that are intellectually challenging and conceptually ambitious, yet deceptively simple and elegant in execution.

Based on a real-life case, its narrative focuses on a man who is put on trial for impersonating a famous filmmaker.  We are swiftly notified that we are watching a blend of documentary and fiction, a sort of dramatised re-enactment in which every person involved in the original events plays themself.

By blurring the boundaries between reality and re-construction, Kiarostami’s film develops into a playfully self-reflexive and quietly engrossing inquiry into the nature of the cinematic image itself - a treat for any cinephile.

See this insane film with us in Old Geo from 5:15pm, with food 'n' drinks beforehand and lively discussion afterwards.

dir. Costa-Gavras - 1969 - France/Algeria
******
If you feeling like working up some political outrage on a Wednesday evening, then come along to our screening of Z.  Drawing heavily from an actual incident that occurred in Greece in 1963, this French-language film portrays the events following the assassination of a prominent politician, tracing a young magistrate’s attempts to uncover the evidence that will allow him to apprehend those responsible.

It’s not hard to see why Z was an international box office hit in its time – it’s a perfectly paced, stylishly directed political thriller underpinned by a blood-boiling story of corruption and conspiracy that maintains its potency today.
******
The usual routine: pizza + drinks at 5pm in Old Geo, film at 5:15pm, drinks and banter afterwards.  See you there!

event_name: FilmSoc Trivia Night @ Manning Bar (Drinks! Pizza! Prizes! Etc.!)
description:
Film fanatics rejoice - FilmSoc's long-awaited night of nights is almost here!

We're going to be hitting up Manning Bar on the 26th of August to deliver you with 6 rounds of film-centric trivia questions.  We'll be starting off with some general knowledge warm-ups, then working towards our infamous final round which will be sure to challenge even the most diehard film junkies.

Of course, we'll be dishing out a ridiculous number of prizes (think DVDs, Blu-Rays and the like), as well as pizza and drink vouchers galore.

Further exciting news: we've got seasoned comedian and quizmaster, Jack Gow, coming in to host!  Y'all are in for an entertaining evening.

FREE for all ACCESS cardholders, $10 for non-ACCESS

Keep an eye on the event page over the coming weeks as we'll be posting all manner of practice questions, sneak peeks and other important updates.
street: Manning House, Manning Rd, University of Sydney

description:
[dir. Cate Shortland - 2012 - Australia/Germany]

Lore is a bildungsroman from an unconventional perspective, set in the aftermath of WWII. After her Nazi parents are captured by the Allied forces, a young girl, Lore, is tasked with taking her siblings through the Black Forest to their grandmother's house. What unfolds is Lore’s realisation of the terrifying disjunct between insular propaganda and the world as it is. In the hands of Australian filmmaker, Cate Shortland, Lore proves to be a poetic and subtly disturbing tale of the dissolution of innocence.

This should be gr8. 5pm pizza and drinks. 5.15pm Screening starts. And afterwards we can swing by the flodge, grab $9 jugs and talk about our feelings. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9W0Zjcazg8o

See you there!

event_name: FilmSoc Week 3: The Man Who Wasn't There
description:
[dir. The Coen Brothers - 2001 - USA]

FilmSoc has always made an effort to look a little outside the obvious when it comes to the Coen brothers, and this year is no exception. The Man Who Wasn’t There is the duo’s take on noir, and while it’s hopelessly dark, it’s also hellishly funny. 

Featuring a strong script and an awesome cast, including Billy Bob Thornton, Frances McDormand and the late James Gandolfini, this is just another showcase of all-round clever filmmaking from the Coens.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=htxvLcSnOU0

Screening at Old Geology Lecture Theatre

Food/drink 5pm, Screening will start at 5.15pm, and we'll head to the Flodge afterwards for drinks and banter.
